habitat_description:
Summer/Breeding:
In northern prairies of Canada and U.S., breeds in short, sparsely to moderately vegetated landscapes that include native grassland and wetland complexes with a variety of wetland classes (ephemeral to semipermanent; Johnson et al. 1998). Tall dense vegetative cover (such as that planted as duck Dense Nesting Cover) is avoided (Higgins et al. 1979, Ryan et al. 1984, Renken and Dinsmore 1987). During breeding period in N. Dakota, foraging individuals preferred ephemeral ponds (normally dry by 1 May), as well as temporary ponds (normally dry by 1 Jun) and alkali wetlands, but semipermanent ponds (usually still wet at freeze-up) often used as well, especially in drier years. Wetlands used have significantly less tall dense cover than unused wetlands; birds used short, sparse vegetation around wetlands more frequently than such habitat was available. Upland habitat selected during breeding primarily idle grassland and pastures; tilled land avoided, but hay fields used in proportion to availability. Preferred native over introduced idle grasslands. Native vegetation composed of green needle grass (Stipa viridula), needle-and-thread (S. comata), blue grama (Bouteloua gracilis), western wheatgrass (Agropyron smithii), and little bluestem (Andropogon scoparius). Domesticated hay species included alfalfa (Medico sativa), sweetclover (Melilotus spp.), and smooth brome (Bromus inermis). Nonnative idle grassland species included smooth brome, introduced grasses Agropyron elongatum, A. intermedium, A. cristatum, quackgrass (A. repens), Kentucky bluegrass (Poa pratensis), and alfalfa (Ryan 1982, Kantrud and Stewart 1984, Ryan et al. 1984). Also in N. Dakota, comparison of grazed native prairie (heavily grazed in May), idle native prairie, and alfalfa-wheatgrass (seeded grass-legume cover established 6+ yr previously) found densities of territorial male godwits greatest in grazed habitats. Idle prairie had significant shrub cover (mostly western snowberry [Symphoricarpos occidentalis]), and denser and more consistently taller vegetation than grazed (Renken and Dinsmore 1987)(quoted directly from Gratto-Trevor 2000).

Winter:
In general (i.e. all regions), winter habitat includes coastal mudflats adjoining savannas or meadows, estuaries, sandy beaches, and sandflats; sometimes roosting at salt ponds (Johnsgard 1979, Colwell 1994, Stevenson and Anderson 1994, Howell and Webb 1995, Page et al. 1997). Also intertidal flats in substrates from consolidated to liquefied flats along water edge. Significant roost sites in nearby marshes (Engilis et al. 1998).
